byline.original: By William E. Geist; William E. Geist writes the ''About New York'' column for The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: He makes it look easy, sitting out there in his hat, sunglasses and tan linen suit at the Cafe de la Paix on Central Park South, tossing off bons mots, sipping cool drinks and smoking cigarettes in Continental fashion. ''Don't kid yourself,'' says Steve DiLeonardi. In order to maintain his status as a New York boulevardier, he must spend hour after hour in the sidewalk cafes of this city, drinking cafe drinks like frozen toasted-almond sherbet daiquiris and dining on such cafe concoctions as chicken, mango and avocado salad with raspberry, lime and hazelnut dressing. during the sidewalk cafe season, commencing and now a running through October, Mr. DiLeonardi has to shell out 20 bucks a week on - boutonnieres! He has big bills for hat cleaning. His sunglasses cost $150 a pair. Sometimes when he is sitting out there, he and his salads are engulfed in clouds of blue exhaust from cars parallel parking just an arm's length from his curbside table. He is showered by muddy water when taxi cabs hit nearby potholes. One must be hearty to be a member of cafe society in New York. ''But people would put up with anything, because we are giving them front-row seats for the greatest show on earth: the sidewalks of New York,'' says Joseph DiCarlo, owner of Sarducci, a restaurant on Seventh Avenue and 16th Street with an outdoor cafe. Mr. DiCarlo says that his customers sit transfixed by the passing flow of pedestrians and that he often has to remind them that they have to get back to work.
